intro: Sida grossulariifolia, commonly known as the blueweed or sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Sida grossulariifolia is often found in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.
